title: fanoutqa: What were the release dates of the studio albums released by the band Destiny's Child? (9eb4feb88c3f980b)

chat_history.content: What were the release dates of the studio albums released by the band Destiny's Child?

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the release dates of all studio albums by the band Destiny's Child."}

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the release date of the first studio album by Destiny's Child."}

chat_history.content: The first studio album by Destiny's Child, titled *Destiny's Child*, was released on February 17, 1998.

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the release date of the second studio album by Destiny's Child."}

chat_history.content: The second studio album by Destiny's Child, titled *The Writing's on the Wall*, was released on July 27, 1999.

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the release date of the third studio album by Destiny's Child."}

chat_history.content: The third studio album by Destiny's Child, titled *Survivor*, was released on April 24, 2001.
chat_history.name: delegate

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the release date of the fourth studio album by Destiny's Child."}

chat_history.content: The fourth studio album by Destiny's Child is *Destiny Fulfilled*, which was released in November 2004.
chat_history.name: delegate

chat_history.content:
Here are the release dates of the studio albums by Destiny's Child:

1. **Destiny's Child** - February 17, 1998
2. **The Writing's on the Wall** - July 27, 1999
3. **Survivor** - April 24, 2001
4. **Destiny Fulfilled** - November 2004

## References[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** St. Asaph, Katherine (June 18, 2017). "Destiny's Child: The Writing's on the Wall". *Pitchfork*. Retrieved February 26, 2023. The result was something of a baby neo-soul album that even Beyoncé admitted was an awkward fit for the then-teens
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Soetan, Sope (February 16, 2023). "Destiny's Child's Debut Album At 25: How A Neo-Soul Album From Teens Spawned R&B Legends". *Grammy.com*. Retrieved February 26, 2023. Yet its "grown and sexy" attitude and neo-soul arrangements weren't an initial hit......The ballad-heavy and traditional R&B style present on Destiny's Child was considered adult-oriented.
3. **^** "ADDvance Notice" (PDF). *Radio & Records*. October 27, 1997. p. 51. Retrieved May 23, 2022 – via World Radio History.
4. **^** "Illusion - Single by Destiny's Child on Apple Music". *iTunes*. February 1998. Archived from the original on 2018-08-10. Retrieved 2018-08-10.

</fragment>
<fragment>

***Destiny's Child*** is the debut studio album by American R&B group of the same name, released by Columbia Records and Music World Entertainment on February 17, 1998. It features the singles "No, No, No" and "With Me", both of which preceded the album. "Killing Time" was also featured in "Men in Black: The Album" and released as a promotional single in 1997. Prior to release, the album was set to be called "Bridges".[5]
The album spent twenty six weeks on the US *Billboard* 200 chart and peaked at number sixty-seven. To date the album has sold a total of 831,000 copies in America. In the United Kingdom, it reached the top fifty, peaking at number forty-five. It was re-packaged and re-released in several countries after the success of the follow-up album, *The Writing's on the Wall* (1999). The album was met with generally favorable reviews from music critics, including AllMusic and *Rolling Stone,* and won a Soul Train Lady of Soul Award for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year.




## Singles[edit]

</fragment>
<fragment>

*Destiny's Child* was a moderate chart success. It debuted at number sixty-nine on the US *Billboard* 200 during the week of March 7, 1998.[10] The album reached it peak at number sixty-seven in its fifth week and spent a total of 26 weeks on the chart.[11] On the *Billboard* Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart the album peaked at number fourteen.[12] In July 1998, the album was certified gold by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) , and later earned a platinum certification on July 11, 2000, for 1 million shipped units.[13] 
Internationally the album album achieved greater success; it reached number twenty-nine on the Canadian Albums Chart, number thirty on the Dutch MegaCharts albums chart and number forty-five on the UK Albums Chart.

<fragment>

As the last release of the album, "Illusion" was released as a promotional single. Remixes by Maurice Joshua were commissioned for this release, where the group re-recorded their vocals exclusively for these remixes.



## Critical reception[edit]




Professional ratings| Review scores |
| --- |
| Source | Rating |
| AllMusic | ![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)[6] |

| *Music Week* | ![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)[8] |
| *Rolling Stone* | ![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)![](image)[9] |


*Rolling Stone* gave the album a mixed review.[9] John Bush of the website AllMusic feels that "Destiny's Child isn't quite just another debut album from an R&B girl group... Their voices sound beautiful together. Still, much of the album sounds indistinguishable from all the other female groups out there.[6]

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>Destiny's Child discography</title>
<fragment>
Destiny's Child first charted in November 1997, and released their self-titled debut album in the United States in February 1998 and it peaked at number 67 on the *Billboard* 200.[1] It earned a platinum certification in the United States by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).[2] The album's lead single, "No, No, No", reached number three on the *Billboard* Hot 100 and was certified platinum by the RIAA.[2] The group's second album, *The Writing's on the Wall*, was released in July 1999, and was their breakthrough release peaking at number 5 on the *Billboard* 200. The first and third single, "Bills, Bills, Bills" and "Say My Name", peaked atop the US *Billboard* Hot 100. The album eventually sold over eight million copies in the United States, gaining eight-times platinum certification by the RIAA.[2] Destiny's Child then released the theme song for *Charlie's Angels*. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

20. **^** "British album certifications – Destiny's Child – Destiny's Child". British Phonographic Industry. Archived from the original on 25 September 2021. Retrieved 25 September 2021.

22. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** "Beyoncé's Albums By The Numbers". *Billboard*. Vol. 121, no. 40. October 10, 2009. p. 46. Archived from the original on February 13, 2023. Retrieved May 8, 2022.
23. **^** O'Brien, Jon (February 17, 2023). "Destiny's Child's Self-Titled Debut Album Turns 25: Songs Ranked From Worst to Best". *Billboard*. Retrieved August 4, 2023.

</fragment>

American R&B girl group Destiny's Child has released five studio albums, five compilation albums, two remix albums, one extended play, twenty-three singles, including four as featured artists and two promotional singles, and three video albums.


</fragment>
<fragment>
To date, Destiny's Child has sold 17.5 million albums in the US and over 60 million records worldwide.[6][7] *Billboard* magazine ranks the group as one of the greatest female acts of all time, and inducted the group in 2008 into the All time Hot 100 Artist.[8][9][10]

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>Destiny's Child discography</title>
<fragment>
Destiny's Child first charted in November 1997, and released their self-titled debut album in the United States in February 1998 and it peaked at number 67 on the *Billboard* 200.[1] It earned a platinum certification in the United States by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).[2] The album's lead single, "No, No, No", reached number three on the *Billboard* Hot 100 and was certified platinum by the RIAA.[2] The group's second album, *The Writing's on the Wall*, was released in July 1999, and was their breakthrough release peaking at number 5 on the *Billboard* 200. The first and third single, "Bills, Bills, Bills" and "Say My Name", peaked atop the US *Billboard* Hot 100. The album eventually sold over eight million copies in the United States, gaining eight-times platinum certification by the RIAA.[2] Destiny's Child then released the theme song for *Charlie's Angels*. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

* BPI: Gold[20]
* MC: 2× Platinum[21]
 | * US: 847,000[22][23]
 |
| *The Writing's on the Wall* | * Released: July 27, 1999
* Label: Columbia
* Formats: CD, MD, Cassette
 | 5 | 2 | 5 | 32 | 21 | 3 | 3 | 6 | 23 | 10
 | * RIAA: 8× Platinum[2]
* ARIA: 3× Platinum[24]
* BPI: 3× Platinum[25][26]
* BVMI: Gold[27]
* IFPI SWI: Gold[28]
* MC: 5× Platinum[21]
* RMNZ: 3× Platinum[29][a]
* SNEP: 2× Gold[30]
 | * World: 13,000,000[31]
* US: 6,400,000[6]
* UK: 1,120,878[32]
 |
| *Survivor* | * Released: April 24, 2001
* Label: Columbia
* Formats: CD, MD, Cassette, Super Audio CD[33]

</fragment>
<fragment>
| Destiny's Child discography |
| --- |
| ![](image) |
| Studio albums | 5 |
| Compilation albums | 5 |
| Video albums | 3 |
| Music videos | 20 |
| EPs | 1 |
| Singles | 23 |


American R&B girl group Destiny's Child has released five studio albums, five compilation albums, two remix albums, one extended play, twenty-three singles, including four as featured artists and two promotional singles, and three video albums.


</fragment>
<fragment>
	* For 101-200 peak positions: "Chart Log UK: Asher D – Dyverse" (scroll down to headings 'Destiny's Child'). *Chart Information Network*. Archived from the original on 28 August 2021. Retrieved 4 September 2021 – via zobbel.de.
20. **^** "British album certifications – Destiny's Child – Destiny's Child". British Phonographic Industry. Archived from the original on 25 September 2021. Retrieved 25 September 2021.
21. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** "Music Canada Gold/Platinum: Destiny's Child". Music Canada. Archived from the original on 2016-06-24. Retrieved 2014-11-05.
22. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** "Beyoncé's Albums By The Numbers". *Billboard*. Vol. 121, no. 40. October 10, 2009. p. 46. Archived from the original on February 13, 2023. Retrieved May 8, 2022.
23. **^** O'Brien, Jon (February 17, 2023). "Destiny's Child's Self-Titled Debut Album Turns 25: Songs Ranked From Worst to Best". *Billboard*. Retrieved August 4, 2023.

</fragment>
<fragment>
To date, Destiny's Child has sold 17.5 million albums in the US and over 60 million records worldwide.[6][7] *Billboard* magazine ranks the group as one of the greatest female acts of all time, and inducted the group in 2008 into the All time Hot 100 Artist.[8][9][10]

## References[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
	* For "Destiny's Child": "RPM Top 100 CDs (March 30, 1998)" (PDF). RPM Magazine. Archived (PDF) from the original on 2016-04-29. Retrieved 2018-12-26.
	* For "The Writing's on the Wall", "Survivor" and "Destiny Fulfilled": "Billboard: Destiny's Child (Billboard Canadian Albums)". *Billboard*. Archived from the original on 2021-11-17. Retrieved 2018-12-26.
	* For "8 Days of Christmas": "Albums : Top 100". *Jam!*. December 13, 2001. Archived from the original on November 25, 2004. Retrieved March 13, 2023.
	* For "This Is the Remix": "Albums : Top 100". *Jam!*. April 4, 2002. Archived from the original on November 12, 2004. Retrieved April 22, 2023.
13. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** "French Charts > Destiny's Child" (in French). lescharts.com Hung Medien. Archived from the original on 2017-01-03. Retrieved 2009-12-02.

</fragment>
<fragment>
The group's third album, *Survivor*, was released in the spring of 2001 and reached number one on *Billboard* 200. The title track reached number 2 in the US and follow-up single "Bootylicious" was their fourth number one song. In March 2002, a remix compilation titled *This Is the Remix* was released.[4] After a three-year hiatus working on solo projects, the group reunited to record their fifth and final studio album, *Destiny Fulfilled*, released in November 2004. The album reached number two in the US and was certified three-time platinum. Four singles were released from the album: "Lose My Breath", "Soldier", "Girl", and "Cater 2 U". The first two singles reached number three in US.[5] A final greatest hits album, *#1's*, was released in October 2005 following their split. 
</fragment>

<fragment>
The group's third album, *Survivor*, was released in the spring of 2001 and reached number one on *Billboard* 200. The title track reached number 2 in the US and follow-up single "Bootylicious" was their fourth number one song. In March 2002, a remix compilation titled *This Is the Remix* was released.[4] After a three-year hiatus working on solo projects, the group reunited to record their fifth and final studio album, *Destiny Fulfilled*, released in November 2004. The album reached number two in the US and was certified three-time platinum. Four singles were released from the album: "Lose My Breath", "Soldier", "Girl", and "Cater 2 U". The first two singles reached number three in US.[5] A final greatest hits album, *#1's*, was released in October 2005 following their split. 
</fragment>

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content: The fourth studio album by Destiny's Child is *Destiny Fulfilled*, which was released in November 2004.

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
